publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland-That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland's economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. Supported by: Michael Russell*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Lord James Douglas-Hamilton*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Dr Elaine Murray*, David McLetchie*, Alasdair Morgan*, Brian Adam*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Nora Radcliffe*

S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland—That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland’s economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. Supported by: Michael Russell, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Dr Elaine Murray, David McLetchie, Alasdair Morgan, Brian Adam, Nora Radcliffe
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Andrew Wilson*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Alex Neil*, Tavish Scott*

S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland—That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland’s economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. Supported by: Michael Russell, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Dr Elaine Murray, David McLetchie, Alasdair Morgan, Brian Adam, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Alex Neil, Tavish Scott
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Mr David Davidson*, Mr Michael McMahon*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Mary Scanlon*, Ben Wallace*

S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland-That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland's economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. Supported by: Michael Russell, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Dr Elaine Murray, David McLetchie, Alasdair Morgan, Brian Adam, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Alex Neil, Tavish Scott, Mr David Davidson, Mr Michael McMahon, Mary Scanlon, Ben Wallace, Alex Fergusson*, Nick Johnston*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Fergus Ewing*, Mr Keith Harding*, Mr Jamie McGrigor*
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Mr Murray Tosh*, Mr Brian Monteith*

S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland-That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland's economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. Supported by: Michael Russell, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Dr Elaine Murray, David McLetchie, Alasdair Morgan, Brian Adam, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Alex Neil, Tavish Scott, Mr David Davidson, Mr Michael McMahon, Mary Scanlon, Ben Wallace, Alex Fergusson, Nick Johnston, Fergus Ewing, Mr Keith Harding, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Mr Murray Tosh, Mr Brian Monteith
S1M-848# ICT in Scotland (lodged on 12 May 2000) Fiona McLeod*

S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland—That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland’s economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. S1M-848# David Mundell: ICT in Scotland—That the Parliament believes that Information and Communications Technology (ICT) infrastructure will play a vital part in Scotland’s economic, social and cultural development; notes with concern that new and emerging technologies such as WAP and ADSL may not be available to everyone in Scotland if only commercial criteria are applied to roll-out, and believes that the Scottish Executive should work together with Her Majesty's Government and with service providers to find ways by license conditions, public funding or otherwise to ensure that Scotland and all its citizens benefit from ICT. Supported by: Michael Russell, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Dr Elaine Murray, David McLetchie, Alasdair Morgan, Brian Adam, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Alex Neil, Tavish Scott, Mr David Davidson, Mr Michael McMahon, Mary Scanlon, Ben Wallace, Alex Fergusson, Nick Johnston, Fergus Ewing, Mr Keith Harding, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Mr Murray Tosh, Mr Brian Monteith, Fiona McLeod, Cathy Jamieson
